Coordinates: Recognition of Shyok Ophiolites of NW Ladakh Trans-Himalaya as a Geoheritage- Importance to Himalayan Orogeny and Remnant of Tethyan Oceanic Lithosphere

Location Description: Trans-Himalaya region of NW Ladakh, along Shyok River
Mention Context: The Shyok Suture Zone exposes one of the best-preserved ophiolitic sequences in the Indian Himalaya, representing remnants of the Tethys Ocean crust.

Location Description: Road transect in Nubra Valley, Ladakh
Mention Context: The route from Diskit to Turtuk traverses key lithologies of the Shyok ophiolite, showcasing pillow basalts, gabbros, and tectonic mélanges.
Excellent exposures of pillow basalts are seen in the Hunder area, indicating submarine volcanic activity of the Tethyan oceanic lithosphere.

Location Description: Between Diskit and Partapur, Nubra Valley
Mention Context: Tegger shows exposures of serpentinized mantle rocks and gabbros that form part of the ophiolitic sequence.

Location Description: Near India-Pakistan border, Baltistan tectonic corridor
Mention Context: The Bukdang–Turtuk area marks the transition from ophiolitic rocks to the Indian continental margin with tectonic mélanges and metamorphic rocks.

Coordinates: Ladakh Himalayan Ophiolites (LHO)- A Geological Heritage of Northwestern India

Location Description: Found in Shyok Suture Zone (SSZ), NW Himalaya, Ladakh
Mention Context: The LHO represents remnants of the oceanic lithosphere formed at divergent plate boundaries and later obducted during the India-Asia collision.

Location Description: Between Hunder and Turtuk, Nubra Valley
Mention Context: The Surmo mélange exposes large tectonic blocks of basalt, radiolarian chert, and ultramafic rocks within a sheared matrix.
The ophiolite exposures between Bukdang and Turtuk are significant for studying the suture zone evolution.
The area shows a near-complete sequence of an ophiolite from mantle to crustal rocks, critical for understanding tectonic stacking.

Type of Geosite: Pillow basalts, sheeted dykes, ultramafic exposures
Mention Context: Both locations exhibit well-developed pillow basalt structures and sheeted dykes—key indicators of ocean floor spreading.

Coordinates: Geological Features of Northwestern Himalaya, Ladakh, India-- Geosites and Their Significance in the Ladakh Himalaya

Type of Geosite: Flysch unit with fossil-rich black shales
Mention Context: Lamayuru is known for its fossiliferous marine sediments, representing deep-water flysch facies of the Indus Basin.

Location Description: Zanskar Gorge region along the Indus River
Type of Geosite: Tectonically active zone with Zanskar shear zone
Mention Context: This region exposes the Zanskar shear zone and the Main Central Thrust (MCT), revealing tectonic processes of the Himalaya.
The Kargil basin preserves evidence of post-collision sedimentation and is significant for tectonic evolution studies.

Location Description: South of Leh, in the Rupshu Valley
Mention Context: Tso Kar represents late Quaternary environmental changes with saline deposits and shorelines, useful for paleoclimate studies.
The region is composed of thick-bedded carbonates showing features of paleo-karstification and early tectonic deformation.

Location Description: Running along the Indus River between Ladakh and Zanskar ranges
Mention Context: The ISZ marks the collisional boundary between the Indian Plate and the Ladakh Batholith/Ophiolites, key to Himalayan tectonics.

Coordinates: Geoheritage in Ladakh Himalaya- the Indus Suture Zone Ophiolites, Southeast of Ladakh, India

Location Description: Along the Leh–Upshi–Nyoma axis, southeastern Ladakh
Mention Context: The ISZ exposes one of the most complete and accessible ophiolite sequences in Ladakh, crucial for reconstructing the closure of the Tethys Ocean.

Location Description: South of Leh, en route to Nyoma
Mention Context: Upshi provides clear exposures of layered gabbros and serpentinized peridotites typical of oceanic crust.

Location Description: Southeast Ladakh, near the India–China border
Mention Context: The area has ophiolitic blocks within sheared matrices, interpreted as subduction-related accretionary complexes.

Location Description: Northeast of Upshi, near Hemis Monastery
Mention Context: The Hemis–Karu belt represents tectonic mixing zones and high-grade ophiolite-associated metamorphic rocks.

Location Description: Between Upshi and Nyoma along the Indus River
Type of Geosite: Tectonic contact zone with thermal springs
Mention Context: Chumathang showcases tectonic contact between batholith and ophiolitic rocks, with active geothermal springs.

Coordinates: A consensus map for Ladakh’s development as potential geotourism destination-- key drivers

Mention Context: Lamayuru’s Moonland landscape is a well-known geotourism attraction due to its surreal terrain and geological exposure of soft laminated sediments.
The Puga geothermal field has been highlighted for its renewable energy potential and geotourism appeal as a natural wonder.
Tso Moriri is a Ramsar site with underlying tectonic significance; potential site for integrated geo-ecotourism development.
Zanskar Valley is considered a key geotourism corridor with exposure to active thrusts, river incisions, and carbonate platforms.

Location Description: Northern edge of Nubra Valley near LoC
Mention Context: The area represents geostrategic and geological significance with ophiolitic traces of the Tethys Ocean crust.
Identified as a potential thematic geotrail showcasing tectonic contact zones, hot springs, and igneous-metamorphic interactions.

Coordinates: Characteristics of Geosites for Promotion and Development of Geotourism in Ladakh, India

Mention Context: Highlighted for its landscape appeal, geological exposure, and existing tourism infrastructure.
Popular stop on Leh highway, said to create an optical illusion of uphill motion.
Identified as a key site for geotourism and geothermal energy research.
Lakes exhibit environmental change indicators, saline deposits, and stunning scenery.

Location Description: Between Upshi and Nyoma along Indus River
Mention Context: Site has geo-medicinal appeal and is ideal for geotourism development.
Cultural and geological integration—suggested for educational tourism.
Recognized for its active tectonic structures and paleogeographic history.

Location Description: North of Upshi, between Leh and Tso Moriri
Mention Context: This area is notable for exposure of the Indus Suture Zone with diverse lithologies.

Coordinates: Geoheritage Sites of Quaternary Loess–Palaeosol and Palaeo-fluvio-lacustrine Deposits in Northwest Himalaya- a Necessitate Protection

Location Description: Roadcut sections between Leh and Basgo
Mention Context: This site reveals multiple Quaternary loess layers with paleosols, offering insights into paleoclimate changes and dust fluxes in the Himalaya.
Loess deposits overlain by aeolian sand dunes—used to study cold desert sedimentation and climate history.

Location Description: On the way to Pangong Tso, near Tangtse
Mention Context: Outcrops represent old lake beds and wind-blown sedimentation linked to glacial–interglacial phases.
Suggested as a Quaternary paleoenvironment archive with evidence of fluvio-lacustrine transitions.
Highlighted as fragile Quaternary archives vulnerable to erosion and construction, needing immediate protection.

Coordinates: Unveiling the geoheritage, cultural geomorphology and geotourism potential of Zanskar region, NW Himalaya, India

Type of Geosite: Karst cave system in carbonate terrain
Mention Context: The Phugtal cave monastery is built into a natural karst cave system in the Paleozoic carbonates of Zanskar—integrating geological and cultural value.
Features evidence of active tectonics and ancient river systems; ideal for geo-education and geomorphological studies.
Geosite integrates Quaternary loess hills and ancient fort architecture — a cultural-geomorphology landscape.

Location Description: On a high hill north of Padum
Type of Geosite: Glacial and river-cut terraces with religious relics
Mention Context: Stongdey is situated on stepped geomorphic terraces — combining spiritual and geomorphological features.
Lingshed Valley showcases periglacial features and rock glacier remnants of Holocene cold periods.

Type of Geosite: Meandering river bends and active thrust zones
Mention Context: Reru marks fluvial geomorphic activity with uplifted terraces and tight river loops indicating tectonic influence.
